body:
Are cookies apart of HTTP Responses natively like that?

Our response objects implement Node.js [OutgoingMessage](https://github.com/DefinitelyTyped/DefinitelyTyped/blob/master/types/node/http.d.ts#L136)

I believe you need to use `fastify-cookie` if you want access to cookies.
It's not about the response but the injected request. you can pass cookies to the inject function.

Ahh I see! I think the best change would be to use the [`light-my-request`](https://github.com/fastify/light-my-request/blob/master/index.d.ts) types to define the `inject` definition as this is what is being used internally anyways. 

Would you like to send a PR?
This issue has been automatically marked as stale because it has not had recent activity. It will be closed if no further activity occurs. Thank you for your contributions.
oops, sorry, I forgot about this one.
The `InjectOptions` interface of light-my-request doesn't declare the `cookies` property either. Shall I file az issue (and a PR) there?

Just open a PR there.

Il giorno mar 3 mar 2020 alle ore 17:44 Gyula Szalai <
notifications@github.com> ha scritto:

> The InjectOptions interface of light-my-request doesn't declare the
> cookies property either. Shall I file az issue (and a PR) there?
>
> â€”
> You are receiving this because you are subscribed to this thread.

> or unsubscribe
> <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AAAMXY7K6X7QYIEMKX3A6ILRFUXWLANCNFSM4KVKTITA>
> .

issue.title: TS types do not cover builder-style .inject() usage

repository.name: fastify
repository.description: Fast and low overhead web framework, for Node.js

issue.body:
## ðŸ› Bug Report

https://github.com/fastify/fastify/blob/master/docs/Testing.md claims that this is legal syntax:

```
fastify
  .inject()
  .get('/')
  .headers({ foo: 'bar' })
  .query({ foo: 'bar' })
  .end((err, res) => { // the .end call will trigger the request
    console.log(res.payload)
  })
```

However, there are only two available types for inject():

```
    inject(opts: HTTPInjectOptions | string, cb: (err: Error, res: HTTPInjectResponse) => void): void
    inject(opts: HTTPInjectOptions | string): Promise<HTTPInjectResponse>
```

Hence builder-style inject fails to compile in TypeScript.

## To Reproduce

Steps to reproduce the behavior:

```js
        const response: fastify.HTTPInjectResponse = await app
          // @ts-ignore
          .inject()
          .get('/endpoint')
        expect(response.statusCode).toBe(200)
```

## Expected behavior

TypeScript compiler correctly accepts inject() without parameters and expects builder to be returned.

## Your Environment

- *fastify version*: >=2.12.1

issue.title: [Snyk] Upgrade fastify from 2.13.0 to 2.13.1

repository.name: FightPandemics
repository.description: This is not the first and last pandemic. Currently, the information about the pandemic is highly fragmented, especially at the local level. Whereas one can find global information and trackers, it is difficult to find information that is relevant to your community. Furthermore, it is difficult for organizations, funders, companies, volunteers and local leaders to coordinate responses. This puts humanity and local communities at risk. FightPandemics was born to make communities more resilient to pandemics by facilitating access to information and coordinated responses.
